Description: Alliance Capital Management L.P. agreed to pay $250 million to settle allegations that it allowed market timing in certain of its mutual funds in exchange for fee-generating investments in other Alliance Capital investment vehicles.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Marcus et al v. AXA Advisors, LLC et al
Meola v. AXA Financial Inc. et al
Magaly Eagan et al v. AXA Equitable Life Insurance Company et al

Description: The New York Attorney General announced a $600 million settlement with Alliance Capital Management -- $250 million in penalties and restitution and $350 million in fee reductions -- to resolve litigation over improper trading and exorbitant fees. The $250 million portion was negotiated together with the Securities and Exchange Commission; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-alliance-capital-management-lp

MONY Life Insurance Company, successor to Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, agreed to pay $250,000 in fines and restitution of the premium plus interest to the organizations involved, in settlement of allegations its agents misrepresented the costs and benefits of a Financial Security Plan it sold to several Connecticut towns.

Company: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States
Description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States agreed to pay $1.6 million in settlement of allegations it misleadingly sold certain life insurance policies.

Company: AXA Equitable Life Insurance Co. et al.
Description: AXA Equitable Life Insurance Company, AXA Equitable Life &  Annuity Company,  MONY Life Insurance  Company, MONY Life Insurance Company of America, and U.S. Financial Life Insurance Company agreed to pay $900,000 to the state as part of a settlement of allegations they had inadequate procedures to ensure policies and other funds were timely investigated and paid out to beneficiaries.

Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Info Source: DEPARTMENT FINES AXA EQUITABLE $1.9 MILLION, States News Service, March 26, 2010 (via Nexis).
Notes: At the time of this case the agency was known as the New York Insurance Department.

Description: The Department of Financial Services announced that AXA Equitable would pay a $20 million fine for violations stemming from an investigation that uncovered that it made changes to certain variable annuity products limiting the potential returns for existing customers without providing adequate notice to DFS.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Equitable Life and Casualty Insurance Company

Description: FINRA fined AXA Advisors, LLC $600,000 and ordered the firm to pay approximately $172,000 in restitution to affected 401(k) retirement plan participants for distributing materials that negligently misrepresented that certain bond funds offered for 401(k) plans were investment-grade when, in fact, a substantial portion of the funds' portfolios consisted of high-yield or junk bonds. As part of the settlement, FINRA also required AXA to send corrective disclosures to all affected plan participants.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered five firms to pay restitution estimated at more than $18 million, including interest, to affected customers for failing to waive mutual fund sales charges for eligible charitable organizations and retirement accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined AXA Advisors, LLC, $1.2 million for failing to adequately supervise its fee-based brokerage business and distributing misleading sales literature for its fee-based brokerage account program, CapAdvantage, between 2001 and 2005. FINRA also ordered AXA Advisors to return $1.4 million in fees to approximately 1,800 customers who were inappropriately placed or kept in fee-based brokerage accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD has fined three distributor a total of $700,000 for violations of NASD's non-cash compensation rules, including improperly providing entertainment and paying for guest expenses at training and education meetings.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed a fine of $350,000 against Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC of New York and a fine of $200,000 against one of the firm's research analysts, for violations of NASD's research analyst conflict of interest rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: AllianceBernstein Investment Research and Management, Inc.
Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined AXA Advisors, LLC $250,000 for failing to obtain sales charge waivers for mutual fund customers through net asset value (NAV) transfer programs. NASD also found that AXA, located in New York City, failed to have an adequate supervisory system in place to identify and provide customers with sales charge waivers to which they were entitled.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
